I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  During  the  2003  Country  Programming  Mission,  the  Government  of  Indonesia 
reconfirmed its request to the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for advisory technical assistance 
(TA) to prepare the Subregional Transport Cooperation Initiative. In April 2003, a Fact-Finding 
Mission visited Indonesia and discussed with the Government the objectives, scope, terms of 
reference  for  consulting  services,  cost  estimates,  financing  plan,  and  implementation 
arrangements  of  the  TA.1  Appendix  1  gives  the  preliminary  TA  framework.  Subregional 
cooperation will help to reduce poverty in the poverty-prone areas of Indonesia. Outputs from 
the TA will support the preparation of the Regional Cooperation Strategy for Southeast Asia. 
 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  General. The recovery of Indonesia and other countries of the Association of Southeast 
Asian Nations (ASEAN) from the 1997 economic crisis opens the door to accelerating economic 
activity in the affected regions. Subregional transport cooperation can play an important role in 
encouraging  cross-border  traffic;  it  can  create  growth  prospects  and  reduce  poverty.  The 
Government underscores the importance of developing a transport strategy for Indonesia to 
develop transport linkages with the Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, and Philippines East ASEAN 
Growth Area  (BIMP-EAGA), and the Indonesia-Malaysia-Thailand Growth Triangle (IMT-GT).  
In Indonesia, BIMP-EAGA and IMT-GT areas include 12 and 7 provinces, respectively. These 
provinces, located in Kalimantan, Maluku, Papua, Sulawesi, Sumatra islands, could benefit from 
expanded  economic  activities  within  BIMP-EAGA  and  IMT-GT.  The  recently  introduced 
administrative  and  financial  decentralization  in  Indonesia,  which  brings  decision-making 
responsibilities  to  the  regional  level,  needs  to  be  exploited  to  nurture  greater  subregional 
cooperation through development of proper transport linkages. 
 
3.   Government Policies and Plans. The Ministry of Communications (MOC) has prepared 
the draft blueprint for long-term (2000-2024) transport development and within this broader plan, 
a 5-year transport sector strategy and plan (RENSTRA and PROPENAS, respectively). The 
plans  clearly  indicate  the  Government’s  policy  to  improve  transport  service  and  promote 
economic prosperity in less developed areas. The draft blueprint emphasizes that subregional 
cooperation can be a means to stimulate demand in the region.    
 
4.   Air Transport. A memorandum of understanding (MOU) to expand air transport linkages 
was  signed  in  1995  by  participating  countries  in  BIMP-EAGA  and  IMT-GT.  The  MOU 
underscores that air linkages will (i) provide access of goods and services for the population 
within the area, (ii) help encourage investments in the area and accelerate intraregional trade 
and promote peace and security. Cooperation involves harmonizing rules and procedures, 
exchanging  pertinent  information,  and  undertaking  programs  and  projects  for  further 
development. The Government has designated four airports as focal points for BIMP-EAGA 
(i.e., Balikpapan, Manado, Pontianak, and Tarakan),2 while three airports (i.e., Banda Aceh,

Medan, and Nias)3 were identified as strategic airports in IMT-GT. Despite a considerably low 
level of transport demand in eastern Indonesia, a subregional air transport network has been 
developed. Air travel tax exemption between Indonesia and the Philippines has also been 
introduced to accelerate travel between the two countries. 
 
5.   Sea  Transport.  The  Government  has  identified  14  ports  under  the  BIMP-EAGA 
program:    Ambon,  Balikpapan,  Banjarmasin,  Biak,  Bitung,  Jayapura,  Kendari,  Makasar, 
Pantoloan, Pontianak, Samarinda, Sampit, Sorong, and Tarakan. Subregional maritime linkage 
has been taking place with the development of a sea transport network of commercial links.4 
Indonesia and the Philippines have also agreed to apply a uniform port tariff. 
 
6.    Road Transport. Indonesia and Malaysia are linked by road transport infrastructure. 
There  are 11  border crossings  between  the  two  countries—8  land  crossings are  between 
Sarawak and West Kalimantan, three are in East Kalimantan. Public transport service runs 
between Pontianak in West Kalimantan and Kuching in Sarawak, via Tebedu and Entikong.   
 
7.    Subregional  Transport  Cooperation  Issues.  The  development  of  subregional 
transport linkages has to address several strategic issues:  
 
(i)  The revealed demand for transport between regions in Indonesia and the rest of 
the sub-region is low,5 especially in the eastern part of Indonesia. However, the 
potential demand for transport may not always be explicitly evident. There can be 
situations  where  new  trade  and  travel  opportunities  emerge  once  transport 
services are provided. 
 
(ii)   The development of the Asian and ASEAN highways will facilitate land cross- 
border traffic between Indonesia and Malaysia. Indonesia will not be able to 
comply with the agreement reached by the ASEAN countries6 since road links 
between Sabah (Malaysia) and East Kalimantan are still missing. All designated 
road cross-border points should also be operational.7  
 
(iii)  The Government has yet to prepare a strategic plan in undertaking the projects8 
discussed and agreed upon by BIMP-EAGA and IMT-GT working groups.  
 
(iv)  The unavailability of a plan and the implementation of subregional transport 
network is due to lack of coordination between agencies of the Government. The 
Coordinating Ministry of Economic Affairs is the focal point for BIMP-EAGA, while 
transport  sector  development  is  under  the  responsibility  of  the  Ministry  of 
Communications and the Ministry of Settlements and Regional Infrastructure. 
Coordination between these agencies is currently weak.

(v)  There is a need to review the strategic airports and ports on the Indonesian side 
to include those in new provinces that recently joined BIMP-EAGA and IMT-GT.  
   
(vi)   The  role  of  regional  governments  will  become  increasingly  important  in  the 
future.9 Their involvement in subregional cooperation is therefore essential and 
has to be considered. 
 
8.   ADB’s  Subregional  Cooperation  Initiatives.  ADB  strongly  supports  regional 
cooperation initiatives in Indonesia10 as stated in the Country Strategy and Program (CSP) for 
Indonesia, 2003-2005. This is further reinforced in the Regional Country Strategy Update for 
Southeast Asia region. The CSP for Indonesia also recommends that ADB conduct sector 
studies  on  nonroad  subsectors  (ferry,  sea,  air)  focusing  on  upgrading  or  addressing  
deficiencies  in  each  system  in  line  with  a  defined  strategic  level  of  service  and  other 
requirements specific to each region. ADB regional technical assistance (RETA) 562511 has 
identified  policy  initiatives  and  programs  for  the  transport  sector  to  enhance  economic 
cooperation  in  BIMP-EAGA.  Meanwhile,  ADB  RETA  555012  has  proposed  some  transport 
projects  to  accelerate  the  development  of  IMT-GT.  While  neither  of  the  two  RETAs  was 
specifically  related  to  the  transport  sector,  ADB  RETA  6013,13  which  is  scheduled  to  be 
completed in 2003, examines possible programs and projects focusing on the transport sector in 
BIMP-EAGA and IMT-GT. Further, ADB RETA 605914 reviews the strategy of implementing 
subregional cooperation in BIMP-EAGA. The World Bank has started the Eastern Indonesia 
Region Transport Project focusing on the road sector, while ADB, through TA 4038-INO, has 
launched the Interisland Transport Project for eastern Indonesia. These projects will promote 
the development of the Indonesian transport linkage to catalyze and reinforce parallel initiatives 
from other members of BIMP-EAGA. Another ADB TA 4144-INO: Private Sector Participation in 
Port  Infrastructure  under  Decentralization  will  help  identify  appropriate  policies  and 
implementing measures for financing Indonesian ports including those in BIMP-EAGA and IMT-
GT. 
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
9.   The  BIMP-EAGA  Development  Strategy  (footnote  12)  suggested  that  participating 
countries focus on the development of productive sectors, such as agriculture, industry, and 
tourism. However, necessary conditions—and the transport sector is considered one of them— 
have yet to be created to promote the productive sectors. While ADB RETA 6013 (footnote 13) 
identifies proposed transport policies and lists of projects for subregional cooperation between 
countries of BIMP-EAGA and IMT-GT, this TA will provide recommendations to the Government 
of Indonesia on necessary actions to follow up the findings of ADB RETA 6013, including 
implementation and financial arrangements for specific projects.  
                                                 
9 Some regional governments have expressed their interest in managing small airports, including those located in 
BIMP-EAGA and IMT-GT, such as Sinabang (Aceh), Muara Teweh, Kotabaru and Tanjung Redep (Kalimantan), 
Banda (Maluku), Wamena, Karubaga, and Inanwantan (Papua), in response to the Minister of Communications 
Decree No 44/2002 on airport decentralization. 
10  This policy will also benefit neighboring countries.

EAGA and IMT-GT Regions. Manila.  
14 ADB. 2002. Technical Assistance for Prioritizing Strategic Directions for the BIMP-EAGA. Manila.

10.   The outcome will be a subregional transport sector strategy for Indonesia that aims to 
eliminate trade and transport barriers, and accelerate economic growth. The strategy will (i) 
identify  requirements, bottlenecks, and missing links in land, air, and sea transport systems; (ii) 
identify TAs and investment projects that can be developed by the public and private sectors, or 
by public-private partnership to eliminate physical and other barriers to development; and (iii) 
prepare action plans to reduce nonphysical barriers to the movement of goods and people 
between Indonesia and neighboring countries. 
 
11.   The  TA  will  provide  (i)  blueprints  and  action  plans  for  subregional  transport  sector 
development in the study area to accelerate cooperation, reduce poverty, and promote peace 
and security; (ii) subregional transport policy initiatives, including institutional arrangements, 
financial and investment strategy, and legal supports, to implement the action plans; (iii) a road 
map to undertake the proposed policies, programs, and projects; and (iv) terms of reference for 
further studies that are necessary for short-term actions. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.   Transport linkages in BIMP-EAGA and IMT-GT will accelerate economic development. 
Balanced infrastructure development across borders will help reduce economic development 
gaps  between  adjacent  areas  and  thus  reduce  poverty  and  help  minimize  social  and 
employment problems. ADB RETA 6013 (footnote 13) has described the existing and potential 
trade  links  in  BIMP-EAGA  and  IMT-GT.  The  methodology  proposed  for  the  TA  strongly 
emphasizes sound program and policy formulation for the subregional development of transport 
linkages in Indonesia to support these trade links. The objective will entail carefully assessing 
the institutional and implementation constraints and consulting with relevant stakeholders in the 
transport sector through workshops.  
 
13.   Key activities will be formulating policy initiatives, pilot programs, and   investment 
projects  to  encourage  subregional  cooperation;  maximizing  economic  impact;  and  helping 
create balanced development in BIMP-EAGA and IMT-GT. Funding policies and mechanisms 
for central/regional governments, state-owned enterprises (SOEs), and the private sector to 
finance  transport  sector  investment  under  decentralization  will  be  key  issues  in  program 
formulation.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing  
14.   The total cost of the TA is estimated to be $500,000 equivalent, of which $275,000 is the 
foreign exchange cost and $225,000 equivalent is the local currency cost. The Government has 
requested ADB to finance $400,000 equivalent covering the entire foreign exchange cost and 
$125,000 equivalent of the local currency cost. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s TA funding program. The Government will finance the balance of the local currency cost, 
equivalent to $100,000 through the provision of office accommodation, Government counterpart 
staff, and cost of compiling origin and destination (OD) data.15 Detailed cost estimates are in  
Appendix 2.   
 
                                                 
15 OD data will be available before the consultants are fielded.

5 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.   The outline terms of reference16 for consulting services to carry out the TA are in 
Appendix 3. The TA will require 23 person-months of consulting services: 10.5 person–months 
international  and  12.5  person-months  domestic.  The  international  consultants  should  have 
expertise  in  (i)  transport  planning  and  policy,  (ii)  transport  economics,  and  (iii)  transport 
financing.  The  domestic  consultants  should  have  expertise  in  (i)  transport  economics,  (ii) 
regional/development economics, (iii) transport planning, and (iv) transport-related regulations 
and institutions. An international consulting firm in association with domestic consultants will be 
recruited in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (April 2002 version) 
using quality-and cost-based selection and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for engaging 
domestic consultants.  
 
16.   The Secretariat General of MOC will be the executing agency (EA) for the TA. The EA 
will provide a counterpart team led by the Planning Bureau of MOC to coordinate TA activities 
and work daily with the consultants.  
 
17.   A  steering  committee  comprising  BAPPENAS,  Coordinating  Ministry  of  Economic 
Affairs,  MOC,  Ministry  of  State-Owned  Enterprises,  Directorate  General  of  Regional 
Infrastructure  (DGRI),  and  Ministry  of  Finance  (MOF)  will  be  established  to  oversee  TA 
implementation.  Local  stakeholders,  including  local  governments,  nongovernment 
organizations, the private sector, and civil society will take part in the consultation process. The 
EA will ensure that all documents, data, and information relevant to the TA are provided when 
needed by the consultants. Office equipment for this TA will be procured by the consultants in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement and will be transferred to the EA upon 
completion of the TA.  
 
18.   The consultants will be fielded in July 2004, and will carry out their work over 6-months 
ending in December 2004.17 They will submit their inception, interim, and draft reports before 
the  end  of  months  1,  3,  and  5,  respectively,  of  the  TA.  Tripartite  meetings  involving  the 
Government, ADB, and the consultants will discuss the findings of the inception, interim and 
draft reports. 
 
 
IV.   THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
 
19.   The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Indonesia for the Subregional Transport Cooperation Initiative, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
A.  Scope of Works 
1.  The consultants’ tasks are described in the following paragraphs. 
 
2.  Collect Data.  Focusing on participating provinces in the Indonesian part of the Brunei, 
Indonesia,  Malaysia,  and  Philippines  East  ASEAN  Growth  Area    (BIMP-EAGA)  and  the 
Indonesia-Malaysia-Thailand  Growth  Triangle  (IMT-GT),  collect  updated  data  on  basic 
macroeconomics  international  transport  links,  and  transport  infrastructure  defined  as  focal 
points in the regions: (i) transport demand characteristics, (ii) transport network characteristics, 
(iii) transport infrastructure specification, (iv) transport operation and service characteristics, (v) 
transport fares, and (vi) transport-related institutional and regulatory aspects of cross border 
procedures.  
 
3.  Assess Data.  Analyze the existing transport systems in Indonesian parts of BIMP-
EAGA and IMT-GT, particularly international transport links. Assess the transport demand and 
identify  transport-related  problems  including  transport  network  and  coverage,  infrastructure 
capacity  constraints,  transport  service  and  operation  problems,  regulatory  and  institutional 
constraints,  transport  infrastructure,  and  service  financing  constraints.  Using  origin  and 
destination  data  provided  by  the  Government,  interview  stakeholders  (travelers,  traders, 
transport operators, tourism agencies, and business communities) to elicit transport and travel 
preferences, constraints, and expectations in the sub-region. 
 
4.  Review Existing Plans and Reports. Review the existing national/regional economic 
development  plans  and  policy  initiatives,  which  are  relevant  to  supporting  subregional 
cooperation (including integrated development areas and regional development cooperation 
initiatives)  and  national/regional  planning  studies/reports,  which  will  form  the  basis  for 
subsequent analyses. Refer also to completed and ongoing studies. Identify the status of these 
plans and studies. 
 
5.  Hold Consultations. Discuss with the Government and other stakeholders subregional 
transport  cooperation  strategies,  including  (i)  the  Government’s  medium-and  long-term 
strategies  and  development  plans  for  transport  subsectors;  (ii)  transport  and  development 
issues; (iii) status of policy reforms; (iv) recommendations of recent policy studies; and (v) 
lessons learned from previous strategies, projects, or other actions that have been taken. 
 
6.  Analyze  the  Transport  Scenario.  Following  review/update  of  existing  data  and 
information, analyze the future transport scenario. Define the gap between the future scenario 
and existing conditions. Identify necessary policies, programs, investments, and conditions to 
achieve  subregional  transport  cooperation,  taking  into  account  ongoing  regulatory  reforms, 
institutional frameworks, decentralization, and financing issues.  
 
7.   Organize  Workshops.  Hold  regional  and  national  consultation  workshops  with  the 
actors  and  stakeholders  in  the  transport  sector,  including  local  governments,  transport 
operators,  transport  users,  nongovernment  organizations,  private  sector,  and  civil  society. 
Organize  the  regional  workshops  in  five  selected  provincial  capitals.  Conduct  the  national 
workshop in Jakarta and invite relevant stakeholders and selected representatives from regional 
governments.

Appendix 3  11 
8.  Develop  Blueprints.  Given  the  objective  to  encourage  and  strengthen  subregional 
transport cooperation, develop transport sector blueprints to overcome/mitigate problems, take 
into account economic development opportunities, and improve transport systems in the study 
area. Also outline a road map to carry out the blueprint for achieving the objectives. Provide 
sound economic analysis to ensure that the policy initiatives and program interventions give 
maximum benefits at the lowest possible costs to society. 
 
9.   List Priority Programs. Prepare a long list of policy initiatives and programs, including 
priority  projects  of  national/regional  governments.  Recommend  priority  programs  to  be 
conducted by the Government and identify areas for Asian Development Bank (ADB) assistance 
and financing, as well as key issues for policy dialogues.  
 
10.   Recommend Programs. Recommend a short list of candidate programs and policy 
initiatives.  For  each  recommended  program,  determine  the  scope  of  work,  identify  the 
implementing  agency  for  program  preparation,  and  identify  the  necessary  conditions  to 
implement the program, including the need for institutional strengthening and financial support. 
Draft the terms of reference for further activities, as a follow-up to the technical assistance (TA). 
 
11.   The Government and ADB will jointly review the consultant’s methodology, findings, and 
recommendations during a tripartite meeting at the end of the project period. ADB and the 
Government will agree on (i) the transport sector blueprint and the road map, (ii) priority areas of 
intervention for the ensuing subregional transport cooperation, (iii) a list of programs and policy 
initiatives, (iv) institutional setting to follow up the findings, and (v)  financial support schemes for 
follow-up actions. 
 
B.  Timing and Reporting Requirements 
12.   The consultants will carry out their work over 6 months. They will submit the inception, 
interim, and draft final reports before the end of month 1, month 3, and month 5, respectively, of 
the  TA.  Tripartite  meetings  involving  the  Government,  ADB,  and  the  consultants  will  be 
organized  to  discuss  the  inception,  interim,  and  draft  final  reports.  Brief  monthly  progress
